site_name: CHARLES Mc GINNIS & DEBBI Mc GINNIS

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
2.40 (b)(2) Direct
When the inspectors were looking at the enclosure housing the two Lasha Apsos they noticed that the male (Cash,
approximately 10 years old microchip ending in 2837) was scooting his butt and whimpering as well as trying to bite at his
rear end. When asked to look at him the inspector noticed a big fecal/hair ball the size of a baseball ball hanging from his
anus. There was also a fecal/hair ball the size of a golf ball hanging in front of his anus where the only way to visualize his
anus was to physically lift away the fecal/hair ball. Upon looking at the anus the inspector noticed it was very red and
inflamed. Poor coat care can lead to matting close to the skin such as the collection of fecal material which can lead to
pain, discomfort and have a negative impact on the animal’s well-being. The licensee must have this dog evaluated by a
licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to establish an effective treatment plan. The licensee must ensure all
dogs receive adequate veterinary care at all times.
To be corrected: April 18, 2025

When starting the inspection, the inspectors noticed a Dachshund (Kye, approximately 2-year-old male with microchip
ending in 6113) that was loose behind the first enclosure they were looking at. One of the inspectors asked the licensee if
she was out last time to which the licensee told them no, she had dug out of her enclosure yesterday morning. The
licensee also stated that he had put concrete blocks in front of the hole in the enclosure and they were in the process of
catching her. Enclosures that don’t contain animals can impact the heath and well-being of the animal, can cause injury
and potentially lead to death. The licensee must ensure that the enclosures for all dogs are kept in good repair and
contain the animals securely.
To be corrected by: April 24, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
WILLIAM HEINE, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
2.40 (b)(2) Direct  
When the inspectors were looking at the enclosure housing the two Lasha Apsos they noticed that the male (Cash, 
approximately 10 years old microchip ending in 2837) was scooting his butt and whimpering as well as trying to bite at his 
rear end. When asked to look at him the inspector noticed a big fecal/hair ball the size of a baseball ball hanging from his 
anus. There was also a fecal/hair ball the size of a golf ball hanging in front of his anus where the only way to visualize his 
anus was to physically lift away the fecal/hair ball. Upon looking at the anus the inspector noticed it was very red and 
inflamed. Poor coat care can lead to matting close to the skin such as the collection of fecal material which can lead to 
pain, discomfort and have a negative impact on the animal’s well-being. The licensee must have this dog evaluated by a 
licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to establish an effective treatment plan. The licensee must ensure all 
dogs receive adequate veterinary care at all times.  
 
To be corrected: April 18, 2025 
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
When starting the inspection, the inspectors noticed a Dachshund (Kye, approximately 2-year-old male with microchip 
ending in 6113) that was loose behind the first enclosure they were looking at. One of the inspectors asked the licensee if 
she was out last time to which the licensee told them no, she had dug out of her enclosure yesterday morning. The 
licensee also stated that he had put concrete blocks in front of the hole in the enclosure and they were in the process of 
catching her. Enclosures that don’t contain animals can impact the heath and well-being of the animal, can cause injury 
and potentially lead to death. The licensee must ensure that the enclosures for all dogs are kept in good repair and 
contain the animals securely.  
 
To be corrected by: April 24, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.

Additional Inspectors: 
WILLIAM HEINE, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
